bibl.title: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Walter Reed, January 15, 1902

div1.p: Kean provides news concerning the Surgeon General position. He has had a conversation with General Wood. Reed should return to Cuba.

div1.head: Letter from Jefferson Randolph Kean to Walter Reed, January 15, 1902
div1.opener:
To Major Walter Reed U.S.A.
Private
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT
OF HAVANA AND PINAR DEL RIO,
QUEMADOS, CUBA.
January 15th 1902-
My Commandante Mio
div1.p:
Yours of the 8th came two
days ago, and before answer-
ing it I determined to tackle
the General for news and
advice- There were various things
which I wanted to ask him
and then I think it is just as
well to consult him & make
him feel that we regard him
as thoroughly committed to our
side, So when I went to him
this morning I went direct to
the Palace and by good luck
caught him on the fly as he
came into his office after
breakfast- I first asked him
if he were going with, & he said
2
no, not unless he were ordered
and as he had done all he
could in the tariff matter
he did not expect to be-
Then I told him about Lagarde
& his biscuit backing- He
replied that Lagarde was not
in it & Westins influence in
this matter was over-rated-
He went in to say that he thought
the matter lay with the Secy
who by the way way is quite familiar
with the work of your board &
regarded it very highly -- and
if they came down into the major
that he thought you would
get it- He brought up Havard
& said he told him that he
was going to try to get you
appointed, but if he found
that they had determined not
to appoint a major but one of
the older men, then he would
support him Havard- He said
3/
this with an air of perfect straight forwardness &
louder and I would bet my head it is just
what he did say- He went on to say that Mr.
Root was especially anxious to find adminis-
trative ability and said that (in substance) the
administration did not want to get hold of
another George M. He asked me if I thought
you had administrative ability, to which I
replied that you had always done every thing
you undertook thoroughly well, and I believed
that you were able to tackle any proposition which
came along- Then I asked him what use you
should make of your professional & scientific
backing & whether the “no influence” pronunciamento
meant anything- That is all talk he said and
meant to keep off jack asses like Ayres & c, but that
the Secy & the President had to consult the opin-
ions of those who knew candidates, as in no
other way could they know about them- He said
that it would do much good to get Welch and
Osler and especially any prominent men in the
profession who knew the Secy to go and see him
and see the President too, and if the thing were
neatly & tactfully done, & the Secy was told who
they were it would be a strong card- He said
they should write too stating how your work was
regarded by the profession, & asking to have their
letters made of record- So much for my
interview and I came away much encouraged
and elated-

Well I wish I could have seen foxy Aleck trying
to pump you with his congratulations- He is a sly bird
4
HEADQUARTERS DEPARTMENT
OF HAVANA AND PINAR DEL RIO,
QUEMADOS, CUBA.
and doubtless gave OR a
faithful -- or rather a full report
of all that you said and
several things that you did
not say- This sounds very
ill-natured & as if I disliked
I. which is not the case
as he is a most entertaining
cuss & I do have a sneaking
fondness for him in spite
of his being such a facile
liar- He has been working
the OReilly boom for a year.

By the way Commandante
there is an alleged Sanitary
Congress to meet here next
month, and while I dont
believe that it will amount
to much it will be a good
excuse for you to run down
to Cuba to see your friends
and satisfy that Viking love of yours for the
sea- I am going to write to Uncle George
Miller on various topics tomorrow such as
a post for next fall & to ask him to appoint
me a delegate to the Assn Military Surgeons
next June -- and I think I will take the
liberty to suggest that as I am neither an
Eminent Scientist like you or an Eminent Sanita-
rian like Gorgas that he appoint you in my
place -- that is if you wish to come-
You should take a last glympse of Cuba
as we will leave it -- and you should also
press home the lessons which you gave with
such telling effect at Buffalo- Gorgas thinks
you ought to be here, and we agreed today
that it would be rare sport if we could get
you & Col. H. into a 16-foot ring with a
large pain of brogans in the middle!
This is that sly Gorgas' suggestion- I have too
much respect for my elders and betters to
make a jest of their proper and honorable
aspirations! well goodbye & good luck to you
my champion- marshall your fellow E.S.s and
march on to victory -- and look not back after
putting your hand to the plough! There is
surely a mixed culture of metaphors for you-
How is old Carroll- I am busy as the deuce getting
ready to turn over my Dept.
